title: China provides anti-mining equipments to Cambodia
description: On November 20, 2017, China provided Cambodia with anti-mining equipment for humanitarian reasons. The equipment delivered includes 40 motors, 14 laptops, ten iPads, 340 military tents, 1,400 wheelchairs, 18 blasting tools, 18 metal detectors, 18 demining tool kits, and 18 protective devices. China’s ambassador to Cambodia Xiong Bo said that contributions on mine clearance will increase the safety of many Cambodians.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China provides anti-mining equipments to Cambodia

# Description
On November 20, 2017, China provided Cambodia with anti-mining equipment for humanitarian reasons. The equipment delivered includes 40 motors, 14 laptops, ten iPads, 340 military tents, 1,400 wheelchairs, 18 blasting tools, 18 metal detectors, 18 demining tool kits, and 18 protective devices. China’s ambassador to Cambodia Xiong Bo said that contributions on mine clearance will increase the safety of many Cambodians.
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid and mine clearance equipment, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-mining equipment for humanitarian purposes, focus on safety and mine clearance

title: Hanban provides grant for the establishment of Mandarin Center at Cambodia’s Ministry of Justice
description: On May 23, 2017, a Mandarin Center officially opened at the Ministry of Justice of Cambodia. Established by the Confucius Institute, the Center provides Chinese language training at beginner and intermediate levels. The center consists of a middle class and two junior classes, for a total of 159 students.
staff_comments: The monetary value of the grant from Hanban that supported this project is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban provides grant for the establishment of Mandarin Center at Cambodia’s Ministry of Justice

# Description
On May 23, 2017, a Mandarin Center officially opened at the Ministry of Justice of Cambodia. Established by the Confucius Institute, the Center provides Chinese language training at beginner and intermediate levels. The center consists of a middle class and two junior classes, for a total of 159 students.
justification: Project focuses on language education without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Mandarin Center providing Chinese language training, educational focus

title: Chinese government provides 18 million RMB for the Preparation of the Intermodal Transport Master Plan Project
description: In 2017, the Chinese government granted 18 million RMB for the Project for the Preparation of the Intermodal Transport Master Plan in Cambodia. The objective is to formulate an "Intermodal Transport Master Plan 2021-2030" to promote Cambodia’s connectivity, reduce transportation and logistics costs, and speed up global integration. The draft plan is prepared by China International Engineering Consulting Corporation (CIECC), led by She Xiangyun, Director of the CIECC team. The start date was June 19, 2018, and the completion date will be June 19, 2020.   The master plan is based on the ‘3.3.4.2’ formula. The first 3 refers to the three main transportation corridors – Phnom Penh-Poipet, Phnom Penh-Bavet, and Phnom Penh-Sihanouk province. The next 3 are the three-sub main transport corridors – the coastal area, the Northeast, and the North. The 4 are the four growth poles – Phnom Penh, Preah Sihanouk, Siem Reap, and Battambang. The 2 refers to the two connected poles, Svay Rieng-Bavet and Banteay Meanchey-Serey Sophon. According to the development of Cambodia's project summary report, the project completion date was 6/19/2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Description
In 2017, the Chinese government granted 18 million RMB for the Project for the Preparation of the Intermodal Transport Master Plan in Cambodia. The objective is to formulate an "Intermodal Transport Master Plan 2021-2030" to promote Cambodia’s connectivity, reduce transportation and logistics costs, and speed up global integration. The draft plan is prepared by China International Engineering Consulting Corporation (CIECC), led by She Xiangyun, Director of the CIECC team. The start date was June 19, 2018, and the completion date will be June 19, 2020.   The master plan is based on the ‘3.3.4.2’ formula. The first 3 refers to the three main transportation corridors – Phnom Penh-Poipet, Phnom Penh-Bavet, and Phnom Penh-Sihanouk province. The next 3 are the three-sub main transport corridors – the coastal area, the Northeast, and the North. The 4 are the four growth poles – Phnom Penh, Preah Sihanouk, Siem Reap, and Battambang. The 2 refers to the two connected poles, Svay Rieng-Bavet and Banteay Meanchey-Serey Sophon. According to the development of Cambodia's project summary report, the project completion date was 6/19/2020.
justification: Project focuses on planning and master plan development for transportation infrastructure without specific energy or environmental components
evidence: Preparation of Intermodal Transport Master Plan, focus on transportation corridors and connectivity, no direct energy or environmental impact mentioned

title: Chinese Government provided loan to Cambodia for National Road No. 7  (NR 7) Water Damaged Road Rehabilitation Project
description: In January 2017, the construction of National Road No. 7 (NR 7) Water Damaged Road Rehabilitation Project in Cambodian was started. According to a source from the implementing agency, Zhejiang Infrastructure Construction Group Co. Ltd., the project is one of the concessional loans or preferential buyer's credit projects (“两优”贷款项目) provided by Chinese government.  Construction officially started in January 2017. On December 14th, 2018, the Construction of Phase 1 is completed. On Jan. 23rd, 2019, the Certificate of giving-receiving the Rehabilitation Project was signed presided over by Cambodian Prime Minister and his Chinese counterpart Li Keqiang, Cambodia and China. It implies that the project has been completed. This project supported a 93.5 km road segment.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 中国援柬7号公路道路水毁修复项目.'Year Uncertain' box is checked because it is unknown if the commitment was made in 2017.Because the project is reported to be one of the concessional loans or preferential buyer's credit projects, it is highly possible that the funding source is Chinese EXIM Bank. However, no evidence is found for this.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provided loan to Cambodia for National Road No. 7  (NR 7) Water Damaged Road Rehabilitation Project

# Description
In January 2017, the construction of National Road No. 7 (NR 7) Water Damaged Road Rehabilitation Project in Cambodian was started. According to a source from the implementing agency, Zhejiang Infrastructure Construction Group Co. Ltd., the project is one of the concessional loans or preferential buyer's credit projects (“两优”贷款项目) provided by Chinese government.  Construction officially started in January 2017. On December 14th, 2018, the Construction of Phase 1 is completed. On Jan. 23rd, 2019, the Certificate of giving-receiving the Rehabilitation Project was signed presided over by Cambodian Prime Minister and his Chinese counterpart Li Keqiang, Cambodia and China. It implies that the project has been completed. This project supported a 93.5 km road segment.
justification: Road rehabilitation project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 93.5 km road segment rehabilitation, general infrastructure focus

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 671 million government concessional loan for Nak Leoung-Thnal Torteung Section of National Road No. 11 (NR 11) Construction Project
description: On May 16, 2017, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed an RMB 671,067,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Nak Leoung-Thnal Torteung Section of National Road No. 11 (NR 11) Construction Project. The GCL carried the following terms: a 20-year maturity, a 7-year grace period, and a 1.25% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC).  The purpose of the project is to construct a  96.48 km segment of National Road No. 11 (NR 11) that runs from Nak Leoung to Thnal Torteung.  NR 11 connects National Road 1 (NR 1) in Prey Veng Province to National Road 7 (NR 7) in Tbong Khmum province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project entered implementation on March 23, 2018, and it was originally expected to reach completion on September 16, 2020. Cambodia’s Minister of Public Works and Transport Sun Chanthol conducted an-site project inspection on May 4, 2020. On December 6, 2021, the Cambodia National Highway was officially opened to traffic.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the National Highway 11 Reconstruction Project and the Construction of National Road No. 11 (NR 11) Project from Nak Leoung to Thnal Torteung. The Chinese project title is 柬11号公路建设项目. The Khmer project title is ផ្លុវ សែនតសូ.2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.

The GCL carried the following terms: a 20-year maturity, a 7-year grace period, and a 1.25% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC).  The purpose of the project is to construct a  96.48 km segment of National Road No. 11 (NR 11) that runs from Nak Leoung to Thnal Torteung.  NR 11 connects National Road 1 (NR 1) in Prey Veng Province to National Road 7 (NR 7) in Tbong Khmum province.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. The project entered implementation on March 23, 2018, and it was originally expected to reach completion on September 16, 2020. Cambodia’s Minister of Public Works and Transport Sun Chanthol conducted an-site project inspection on May 4, 2020. justification: Road construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 96.48 km road segment construction, transportation infrastructure focus

title: Chinese Government provides $14 million grant for Phase 1 of Rural Road Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#61781)
description: In 2017, the Chinese Government provided US $14 million grant for the First Phase of Rural Road Renovation Project (or First Phase of Rural Road Improvement Project or 柬埔寨乡村道路项目一期通).   Phase I of the project was started in July 2017, and it included the construction of 6 roads and one bridge: in the Kampong Speu Province, a 125-meter bridge was constructed and connected to the road, while in Kampong Cham, Kampong Thom, and Kampong Chhnang City, 6 rural roads are renovated with a total length of 35.5 kilometers. Shanghai Construction Engineering Group (SCG) was responsible for the construction. Phase I was completed on May 28, 2019.  This project is linked to Project ID#61781, which captures the second phase of the Rural Road Renovation Project.
combined_text:

title: Henan Transportation Investment Group donates transport maintenance equipment
description: On July 21, 2017, the handover ceremony of Henan Transportation Investment Group's, machinery and equipment aid to Cambodia was held in Phnom Penh. The Cambodian Minister of State and Minister of Public Transport and Engineering Sun Zhanto, Li An, Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Cambodia, and Cheng Risheng, Chairman of Henan Transportation Investment Group Co., Ltd., known as 河南交通投资集团 in Chinese, attended the handover ceremony.   The equipment presented by Henan Transportation Investment Group includes one bridge inspection vehicle, one asphalt gravel spreading vehicle, one aerial work vehicle, one wrecker, as well as 4 sets of new asphalt pavement minor repair and maintenance equipment.
combined_text:

TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

Henan Transportation Investment Group donates transport maintenance equipment

On July 21, 2017, the handover ceremony of Henan Transportation Investment Group's, machinery and equipment aid to Cambodia was held in Phnom Penh. The equipment presented by Henan Transportation Investment Group includes one bridge inspection vehicle, one asphalt gravel spreading vehicle, one aerial work vehicle, one wrecker, as well as 4 sets of new asphalt pavement minor repair and maintenance equipment.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 388.7 million government concessional loan for Eighth Cambodia-China Friendship Bridge Stung Treng-Krouch Chhmar (Phase 1 of National Road No. 71 C) Project (Linked to #92544)
description: On May 16, 2017, at the 2017 “Belt and Road” International Cooperation Summit Forum and under the joint witness of Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and Prime Minister Hun Sen of the Royal Government of Cambodia, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed an RMB 388,762,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Eighth Cambodia-China Friendship Bridge Stung Treng-Krouch Chhmar (Phase 1 of National Road No. 71 C) Project. The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 1.25% interest rate.  The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG). The purpose of the project is to construct a 1.13 km reinforced concrete bridge — that crosses the Mekong River — and an 8.3-km connecting road. The Stung Trang-Kroch Chhmar Bridge is 13.5 meters wide and 15 meters high and it located in Boeung Deng Village, Prek Kak Commune, Stung Trang District, and Kampong Cham Province. This project is considered to be the first phase of the National Highway No. 71C, which will run from Stung Treng district in Tbong Khmum Province to Chamka Leu district in Kampong Cham Province.  SCG was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. On May 16, 2016, an inspection of National Highway No. 71C was undertaken to gauge the feasibility of building and repairing the road. The project officially commenced on February 9, 2018, and construction was originally expected to be complete in early 2021.  As of February 2020, the project was 84% complete. As of July 3, 2020, the project was 87% complete. As of December 7, 2020, the project was 96.4% complete. On November 23, 2021, Cambodian Prime Minister Samdech Techo Hun Sen cut the ribbon to inaugurate the Eighth Cambodia-China Friendship Bridge.
staff_comments: The project is also known as the Eighth Cambodia-China Friendship Bridge or Stung Trang-Krauch Chhmar Bridge Over Mekong River Project, Phase Ⅰ of the National Road 71C Project, the Stueng Trang - Krouch Chhmar Bridge Project, or the Stueng Trang-Grochma Bridge and Connecting Road Project. The Chinese project title is 柬斯登特朗-格罗奇马湄公河大桥项目 or 第八座柬中友谊大桥 or 71C号国家公路项目一期工程. The second phase of the project is captured in project #92544. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:

The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 1.25% interest rate.  The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract with Shanghai Construction Group (SCG). The purpose of the project is to construct a 1.13 km reinforced concrete bridge — that crosses the Mekong River — and an 8.3-km connecting road. The Stung Trang-Kroch Chhmar Bridge is 13.5 meters wide and 15 meters high and it located in Boeung Deng Village, Prek Kak Commune, Stung Trang District, and Kampong Cham Province. title: Chinese government holds agricultural expert training workshop for 50 Cambodian officials
description: On August 22, 2017, three Chinese senior experts provided a three-day training course workshop. The workshop helped train some 50 Cambodian agriculture officials on construction and management of laboratory and technology of agriculture mechanization and horticulture development. Li An, Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy to Cambodia, said China was very pleased to see fruitful cooperation between China and Cambodia in all fields, including agriculture.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese government holds agricultural expert training workshop for 50 Cambodian officials

# Description
On August 22, 2017, three Chinese senior experts provided a three-day training course workshop. The workshop helped train some 50 Cambodian agriculture officials on construction and management of laboratory and technology of agriculture mechanization and horticulture development. Li An, Economic and Commercial Counselor of the Chinese Embassy to Cambodia, said China was very pleased to see fruitful cooperation between China and Cambodia in all fields, including agriculture.
justification: Project focuses on knowledge transfer and capacity building in agriculture without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agricultural expert training workshop, focus on laboratory management and horticulture development

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 116.6 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project (Eastern Loop Line Part II) (Linked to Project ID#62337 and #62335, #62321)
description: On May 16, 2017, China Eximbank and Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed an RMB 116,620,120 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 2 of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project (Eastern Loop Line Part II). The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract between Electricite du Cambodge (EDC) — the country’s state-owned electricity utility — and China National Heavy Machinery Corporation (CHMC), which was signed on February 16, 2017.  Phase 2 of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project was implemented in two parts and financed with two separate China Eximbank loans. Part I is captured in Project ID#62337, and Part II is captured in this project.  Part II of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project involved the construction of four new 230kV substations (including the Kampong Thom substation, the East Phnom Penh substation), the expansion of seven existing 230kV substations (including the Stung Treng substation and the Kratie substation), the construction of an 85km, 230kV double circuit transmission line from switchyard of Tatay hydropower station to the Botom Sarkor substation, and the construction of a 72 km, 115kV transmission line from Ream to Chamkar Loung. Upon completion, the project was expected to deliver power to 250,000 non-electrified households and address the electricity needs of 850,000 users.  CHMC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Part II commenced on July 1, 2017 and it was expected to reach completion on May 16, 2020. As of March 2021, it was unclear if this project had reached completion.  Phase 1 of 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project was also completed in two sections- both of which were financed by China Eximbank PBC loans: the Tonle Sap Lake Loop Line section, which is captured in Project ID#62335, and the Phnom Penh Loop Line section, which is captured in ProjectID#62321.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Transmission Line 230 KV Project Phase II (Loop Line in Eastern Part of Cambodian National Grid Part II) or Phase 2 of the 230 KV Loop Transmission Line Project (Southwest Loop Line and Eastern Loop Line Part I).  The Chinese project title is 柬埔寨国家电网230kV输变电二期项目（东部环网第一部).The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 116.6 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project (Eastern Loop Line Part II) (Linked to Project ID#62337 and #62335, #62321)

# Description
On May 16, 2017, China Eximbank and Cambodia's Ministry of Economy and Finance signed an RMB 116,620,120 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase 2 of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project (Eastern Loop Line Part II). The GCL carried the following terms: 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance an EPC (commercial) contract between Electricite du Cambodge (EDC) — the country’s state-owned electricity utility — and China National Heavy Machinery Corporation (CHMC), which was signed on February 16, 2017.  Phase 2 of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project was implemented in two parts and financed with two separate China Eximbank loans. Part I is captured in Project ID#62337, and Part II is captured in this project.  Part II of the 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project involved the construction of four new 230kV substations (including the Kampong Thom substation, the East Phnom Penh substation), the expansion of seven existing 230kV substations (including the Stung Treng substation and the Kratie substation), the construction of an 85km, 230kV double circuit transmission line from switchyard of Tatay hydropower station to the Botom Sarkor substation, and the construction of a 72 km, 115kV transmission line from Ream to Chamkar Loung. Upon completion, the project was expected to deliver power to 250,000 non-electrified households and address the electricity needs of 850,000 users.  CHMC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Part II commenced on July 1, 2017 and it was expected to reach completion on May 16, 2020. As of March 2021, it was unclear if this project had reached completion.  Phase 1 of 230 kV Loop Transmission Line Project was also completed in two sections- both of which were financed by China Eximbank PBC loans: the Tonle Sap Lake Loop Line section, which is captured in Project ID#62335, and the Phnom Penh Loop Line section, which is captured in ProjectID#62321.
justification: Project focuses on electrical transmission infrastructure without clear renewable energy integration
evidence: Construction of new 230kV substations, expansion of existing substations, and construction of transmission lines to improve grid capacity and reliability
